this seems key - juvenile incarceration breeds more incarceration, therefore getting youth out of the pipeline lowers future population. "tough on crime" measures sentencing youth as adults & building a criminal record are crimogenic and fosters future (longer) incarceration.

shuttering nci seems like a no-brainer. pre-covid it was barely used & it reflects a broken, punitive, control-based correctional philosophy that we should leave behind. take away that tool so it can’t be used.

last time ct's correctional population was this low was april 8, 1991. of note 3 years before that it was *7,500.* ct population in 2020 3.7m, 1988 3.2m. important questions: 1) what are parole/probation 's doing? 2) how do we keep it low post-covid? 3) how do we go lower?
also the bureau of justice statistics is also underfunded & always 2-3 years behind.

some jurisdictions do better than others (nyc & la open data for example) but others not at all - likely mostly in response to activists & reformers. also, only recently did nys share data on where incarcerated are *from* not where the *are.* don't know any other states that do.
